trans-unit.source: Using offline data in Mobile Services (Windows Phone) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Using offline data in Mobile Services (Windows Phone) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services with sync offline data in your Windows Phone application
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services with sync offline data in your Windows Phone application

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use use the offline capabilities of Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use use the offline capabilities of Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Services offline features allow you to interact with a local database when you are in an offline scenario with your Mobile Service.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Services offline features allow you to interact with a local database when you are in an offline scenario with your Mobile Service.

trans-unit.source: The offline features allow you to sync your local changes with the mobile service when you are online again.
trans-unit.target: The offline features allow you to sync your local changes with the mobile service when you are online again.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will update the app from the [Get Started with Data] tutorial to support the offline features of Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will update the app from the [Get Started with Data] tutorial to support the offline features of Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Then you will add data in a disconnected offline scenario, sync those items to the online database, and then log in to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.
trans-unit.target: Then you will add data in a disconnected offline scenario, sync those items to the online database, and then log in to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is intended to help you better understand how Mobile Services enables you to use Azure to store and retrieve data in a Windows Phone app.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is intended to help you better understand how Mobile Services enables you to use Azure to store and retrieve data in a Windows Phone app.

trans-unit.source: If this is your first experience with Mobile Services, consider first completing the [Get started with Mobile Services] and [Get Started with Data] tutorials.
trans-unit.target: If this is your first experience with Mobile Services, consider first completing the [Get started with Mobile Services] and [Get Started with Data] tutorials.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through these basic steps:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through these basic steps:

trans-unit.source: [Update the app to support offline features]
trans-unit.target: [Update the app to support offline features]

trans-unit.source: [Test the app in an offline scenario]
trans-unit.target: [Test the app in an offline scenario]

trans-unit.source: [Update the app to reconnect your mobile service]
trans-unit.target: [Update the app to reconnect your mobile service]

trans-unit.source: [Test the app connected to the Mobile Service]
trans-unit.target: [Test the app connected to the Mobile Service]

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires the following:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires the following:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2012
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2012

trans-unit.source: [Windows Phone 8 SDK]
trans-unit.target: [Windows Phone 8 SDK]

trans-unit.source: Completion of the [Get Started with Data] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Completion of the [Get Started with Data] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SDK version 1.3.0 (or later)[mobile services sdk nuget]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SDK version 1.3.0 (or later)[mobile services sdk nuget]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SQLite Store version 1.0.0 (or later)[sqlite store nuget]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SQLite Store version 1.0.0 (or later)[sqlite store nuget]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: [SQLite for Windows Phone 8]
trans-unit.target: [SQLite for Windows Phone 8]

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need a Azure account.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need a Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see Azure Free Trial.
trans-unit.target: For details, see Azure Free Trial.

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Services offline features allow you to interact with a local database when you are in an offline scenario with your Mobile Service.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Services offline features allow you to interact with a local database when you are in an offline scenario with your Mobile Service.

trans-unit.source: To use these features in your app, you initialize MobileServiceClient.SyncContext to a local store.
trans-unit.target: To use these features in your app, you initialize MobileServiceClient.SyncContext to a local store.

trans-unit.source: Then reference your table through the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface.
trans-unit.target: Then reference your table through the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface.

trans-unit.source: This section uses SQLite as the local store for the offline features.
trans-unit.target: This section uses SQLite as the local store for the offline features.

trans-unit.source: You can skip this section and just download a version of the Getting Started project that already has offline support.
trans-unit.target: You can skip this section and just download a version of the Getting Started project that already has offline support.

trans-unit.source: To download a project with offline support enabled, see [Getting Started Offline Sample for Windows Phone].
trans-unit.target: To download a project with offline support enabled, see [Getting Started Offline Sample for Windows Phone].

trans-unit.source: Install SQLite for Windows Phone 8 projects.
trans-unit.target: Install SQLite for Windows Phone 8 projects.

trans-unit.source: You can install it from this link, [SQLite for Windows Phone 8].
trans-unit.target: You can install it from this link, [SQLite for Windows Phone 8].

trans-unit.source: If you are using Internet Explorer, clicking the link to install SQLite may prompt you to download the .vsix as a .zip file.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Internet Explorer, clicking the link to install SQLite may prompt you to download the .vsix as a .zip file.

trans-unit.source: Save the file to a location on your hard drive with the .vsix extension instead of .zip.
trans-unit.target: Save the file to a location on your hard drive with the .vsix extension instead of .zip.

trans-unit.source: The double click the .vsix file in Windows Explorer to run the installation.
trans-unit.target: The double click the .vsix file in Windows Explorer to run the installation.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio open the project that you completed in the [Get started with Mobile Services] or [Get Started with Data] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio open the project that you completed in the [Get started with Mobile Services] or [Get Started with Data] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click References under the project and add a reference to SQLite for Windows Phone under Windows Phone>Extensions.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click References under the project and add a reference to SQLite for Windows Phone under Windows Phone>Extensions.

trans-unit.source: The SQLite Runtime requires you to change the processor architecture of the project being built to x86, x64, or ARM.
trans-unit.target: The SQLite Runtime requires you to change the processor architecture of the project being built to x86, x64, or ARM.

trans-unit.source: Any CPU is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Any CPU is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Change the processor architecture to one of the supported settings that you want to test.
trans-unit.target: Change the processor architecture to one of the supported settings that you want to test.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, right click your client app project and click Manage Nuget Packages to run NuGet Package Manager.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, right click your client app project and click Manage Nuget Packages to run NuGet Package Manager.

trans-unit.source: Search for SQLiteStore to install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore package.
trans-unit.target: Search for SQLiteStore to install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore package.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open the MainPage.xaml.cs file.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open the MainPage.xaml.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Add the following using statements to the top of the file.
trans-unit.target: Add the following using statements to the top of the file.

trans-unit.source: In Mainpage.xaml.cs replace the declaration of todoTable with a declaration of type IMobileServicesSyncTable that is initialized by calling MobileServicesClient.GetSyncTable().
trans-unit.target: In Mainpage.xaml.cs replace the declaration of todoTable with a declaration of type IMobileServicesSyncTable that is initialized by calling MobileServicesClient.GetSyncTable().

trans-unit.source: In MainPage.xaml.cs, update the TodoItem class so that the class includes the Version system property as follows.
trans-unit.target: In MainPage.xaml.cs, update the TodoItem class so that the class includes the Version system property as follows.

trans-unit.source: In MainPage.xaml.cs, update the OnNavigatedTo event handler so that it is an async method and initializes the client sync context with a SQLite store.
trans-unit.target: In MainPage.xaml.cs, update the OnNavigatedTo event handler so that it is an async method and initializes the client sync context with a SQLite store.

trans-unit.source: The SQLite store is created with a table that matches the schema of the mobile service table but it must contain the Version system property added in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: The SQLite store is created with a table that matches the schema of the mobile service table but it must contain the Version system property added in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open the MainPage.xaml file.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open the MainPage.xaml file.

trans-unit.source: Find the button definition for the Refresh button.
trans-unit.target: Find the button definition for the Refresh button.

trans-unit.source: Replace it with the following stack panel defintion.
trans-unit.target: Replace it with the following stack panel defintion.

trans-unit.source: This code adds two button controls with click event handlers for Push and Pull operations.
trans-unit.target: This code adds two button controls with click event handlers for Push and Pull operations.

trans-unit.source: The buttons are horizontally where the refresh button is.
trans-unit.target: The buttons are horizontally where the refresh button is.

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: Also, change the text for the textblocks to match the following screenshot.
trans-unit.target: Also, change the text for the textblocks to match the following screenshot.

trans-unit.source: In MainPage.xaml.cs, add the button click event handlers for the Push and Pull buttons and save the file.
trans-unit.target: In MainPage.xaml.cs, add the button click event handlers for the Push and Pull buttons and save the file.

trans-unit.source: Don't run the app yet.
trans-unit.target: Don't run the app yet.

trans-unit.source: Press the F7 key to rebuild the project.
trans-unit.target: Press the F7 key to rebuild the project.

trans-unit.source: Verify no build errors occurred.
trans-unit.target: Verify no build errors occurred.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you break the app connection with the mobile service to simulate an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you break the app connection with the mobile service to simulate an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: Then you will add some data items which will be held in the local store.
trans-unit.target: Then you will add some data items which will be held in the local store.

trans-unit.source: Notice that in this section the app should not be connected to any mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Notice that in this section the app should not be connected to any mobile service.

trans-unit.source: So the Push and Pull buttons will throw exceptions if you test them.
trans-unit.target: So the Push and Pull buttons will throw exceptions if you test them.

trans-unit.source: In the next section, you will connect this client app to the mobile service again to test the Push and Pull operations to sync the store with the mobile service database.
trans-unit.target: In the next section, you will connect this client app to the mobile service again to test the Push and Pull operations to sync the store with the mobile service database.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open App.xaml.cs.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open App.xaml.cs.

trans-unit.source: Change the initialization of the MobileServiceClient to a invalid address by replacing "azure-mobile.net" with "azure-mobile.xxx" for your URL.
trans-unit.target: Change the initialization of the MobileServiceClient to a invalid address by replacing "azure-mobile.net" with "azure-mobile.xxx" for your URL.

trans-unit.source: Then save the file.
trans-unit.target: Then save the file.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press F5 to build and run the app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press F5 to build and run the app.

trans-unit.source: Enter a new todo item and click Save.
trans-unit.target: Enter a new todo item and click Save.

trans-unit.source: The new todo items exist only in the local store until they can be pushed to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The new todo items exist only in the local store until they can be pushed to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The client app behaves as if its connected to the mobile service supporting all create, read, update, delete (CRUD) operations.
trans-unit.target: The client app behaves as if its connected to the mobile service supporting all create, read, update, delete (CRUD) operations.

trans-unit.source: Close the app and restart it to verify that the new items you created are persisted to the local store.
trans-unit.target: Close the app and restart it to verify that the new items you created are persisted to the local store.

trans-unit.source: In this section you reconnect the app to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In this section you reconnect the app to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This simulates the app moving from an offline state to an online state with the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This simulates the app moving from an offline state to an online state with the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open App.xaml.cs.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open App.xaml.cs.

trans-unit.source: Change the initialization of the MobileServiceClient back to the correct address by replacing "azure-mobile.xxx" with "azure-mobile.net" for your URL.
trans-unit.target: Change the initialization of the MobileServiceClient back to the correct address by replacing "azure-mobile.xxx" with "azure-mobile.net" for your URL.

trans-unit.source: Then save the file.
trans-unit.target: Then save the file.

trans-unit.source: In this section you will test push and pull operations to sync the local store with the mobile service database.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will test push and pull operations to sync the local store with the mobile service database.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to rebuild and run the app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to rebuild and run the app.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the data looks the same as the offline scenario even though the app is now connected to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the data looks the same as the offline scenario even though the app is now connected to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This is because this app always works with the IMobileServiceSyncTable that is pointed to the local store.
trans-unit.target: This is because this app always works with the IMobileServiceSyncTable that is pointed to the local store.

trans-unit.source: Log into the Microsoft Azure Management portal and look at the database for your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Log into the Microsoft Azure Management portal and look at the database for your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: If your service uses the JavaScript backend for mobile services, you can browse the data from the Data tab of the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: If your service uses the JavaScript backend for mobile services, you can browse the data from the Data tab of the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the .NET backend for your mobile service, in Visual Studio go to Server Explorer -> Azure -> SQL Databases.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the .NET backend for your mobile service, in Visual Studio go to Server Explorer -> Azure -> SQL Databases.

trans-unit.source: Right click your database and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Right click your database and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Notice the data has not been synchronized between the database and the local store.
trans-unit.target: Notice the data has not been synchronized between the database and the local store.

trans-unit.source: In the app, press the Push button.
trans-unit.target: In the app, press the Push button.

trans-unit.source: This causes the app to call MobileServiceClient.SyncContext.PushAsync and then RefreshTodoItems to refresh the app with the items from the local store.
trans-unit.target: This causes the app to call MobileServiceClient.SyncContext.PushAsync and then RefreshTodoItems to refresh the app with the items from the local store.

trans-unit.source: This push operation results in the mobile service database receiving the data from the store.
trans-unit.target: This push operation results in the mobile service database receiving the data from the store.

trans-unit.source: However, the local store does not receive the items from the mobile service database.
trans-unit.target: However, the local store does not receive the items from the mobile service database.

trans-unit.source: A push operation is executed off the MobileServiceClient.SyncContext instead of the IMobileServicesSyncTable and pushes changes on all tables associated with that sync context.
trans-unit.target: A push operation is executed off the MobileServiceClient.SyncContext instead of the IMobileServicesSyncTable and pushes changes on all tables associated with that sync context.

trans-unit.source: This is to cover scenarios where there are relationships between tables.
trans-unit.target: This is to cover scenarios where there are relationships between tables.

trans-unit.source: In the app a few new items to the local store.
trans-unit.target: In the app a few new items to the local store.

trans-unit.source: This time press the Pull button in the app.
trans-unit.target: This time press the Pull button in the app.

trans-unit.source: The app only calls IMobileServiceSyncTable.PullAsync() and RefreshTodoItems.
trans-unit.target: The app only calls IMobileServiceSyncTable.PullAsync() and RefreshTodoItems.

trans-unit.source: Notice that all the data from the mobile service database was pulled into the local store and shown in the app.
trans-unit.target: Notice that all the data from the mobile service database was pulled into the local store and shown in the app.

trans-unit.source: However, also notice that all the data in the local store was still pushed to the mobile service database.
trans-unit.target: However, also notice that all the data in the local store was still pushed to the mobile service database.

trans-unit.source: This is because a pull always does a push first.
trans-unit.target: This is because a pull always does a push first.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we retrieve all records in the remote todoTable, but it is also possible to filter records by passing a query.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we retrieve all records in the remote todoTable, but it is also possible to filter records by passing a query.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter to PullAsync is a query ID that is used for incremental sync, which uses the UpdatedAt timestamp to get only records modified since the last sync.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter to PullAsync is a query ID that is used for incremental sync, which uses the UpdatedAt timestamp to get only records modified since the last sync.

trans-unit.source: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.
trans-unit.target: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.

trans-unit.source: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass null as the query ID.
trans-unit.target: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass null as the query ID.

trans-unit.source: This will retrieve all records on each pull operation, which is potentially inefficient.
trans-unit.target: This will retrieve all records on each pull operation, which is potentially inefficient.

trans-unit.source: To support synchronization of deleted records with offline data sync, you should enable [Soft Delete].
trans-unit.target: To support synchronization of deleted records with offline data sync, you should enable [Soft Delete].

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, you have to call IMobileServiceSyncTable.PurgeAsync() to purge the local store.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, you have to call IMobileServiceSyncTable.PurgeAsync() to purge the local store.

trans-unit.source: [Handling conflicts with offline support for Mobile Services]
trans-unit.target: [Handling conflicts with offline support for Mobile Services]

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Using Soft Delete in Mobile Services[soft delete]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Using Soft Delete in Mobile Services[soft delete]</linkText><title></title>
